title: Skodnick: Mets fans have undeniable passion
text:
Skodnick: Mets fans have undeniable passion Leif S. Skodnick , The Journal News 5:28 p.m. EDT October 8, 2015 The Mets' acquistion of Yoenis Cespedes at the trade deadline sparked the team's run to an unexpected National League East championship. (Photo: Jim McIsaac) 12 CONNECT 4 TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
Thirteen years ago in mid-September, a friend and I traveled to watch two of Major League Baseball's saddest sacks, the last-place-in-the-standings Mets play the last-place-in-attendance Montreal Expos duke it out in a three-game set at Olympic Stadium, the cavernous, heavily indebted relic in the death throes of its role as a ballpark. 
Plunking down $5 (Canadian) apiece for each of the three games, we were two among rare crowds that numbered above 10,000, the majority of whom were Mets fans that followed the Thruway to the Northway to Autoroute 15 to Rue Sherbrooke for what many thought would be the Mets' final visit to The Big O. 
That Sunday, Bobby Valentine's final Mets club, 25 games out of first place and nine games under .500, started a lineup of rookies (Ty Wigginton at second base, Jeff Duncan in center field) and re-treads and aging regulars (Joe McEwing at shortstop, Jeromy Burnitz in right field, Mo Vaughn at first base, Edgardo Alfonso at third base) who were having mostly unremarkable seasons both individually and as a team. 
In the row in front of us, a father and his young son of six or eight years of age, clad in blue and orange, chomped Lafleur hot dogs and swigged Cokes as the Expos, behind an unheralded lineup featuring one bonafide star, made easy work of the Mets 10-3. 
But throughout that game, for Mets Dad and Mets Son, hope sprung eternal, with father reminding son of the potential of New York's remaining hitters, despite the fact that Burnitz was barely hitting over .200, Vaughn's best days were at least four seasons behind him, and the offerings of every pitcher in the league seemed like Kryptonite to "Super Joe" McEwing. 
That's the kind of optimism that comes with being a passionate Mets fan — and Mets fans are nothing if not passionate. 
We've certainly heard from that passionate fan base at this newspaper as the National Leaguers in Queens put together an unlikely division championship that reversed eight seasons of futile history — the prospects (Michael Conforto, Noah Syndergaard, Travis d'Arnaud) panned out into Major League regulars, Matt Harvey mended and returned to full form, and Bartolo Colon picked up 14 wins at age 42 and humored us with his at-bats along the way. 
And perhaps most importantly, after Fred Wilpon and Sandy Alderson were finally buyers at the trade deadline, bringing in Yoenis Cespedes and Tyler Clippard to join a team that was four games over .500 on August 1 and pushing them to a 90-72 record on the season's 180th day. 
Over the past two months, Mets fans have called, asking why we send Chad Jennings (who will be covering the Mets during the playoffs) to the Yankees' games when the Mets are the best team in New York. They've emailed, asking why there have been three articles on the Yankees on a given day and only one on the Mets. If we had our way, we'd have a reporter at every Mets game — and in that same ideal situation, we'd have a reporter for every high school sports beat, for tennis, Army football, and recreational sports — but unfortunately the realities of the modern news business limit our resources. 
While Yankees fans greatly outnumber Mets fans in Westchester, Rockland, and Putnam, there's no denying the amazing passion of Amazins' fans. 
It reminded me, after more than a dozen years, of that father and son traveling eight hours only to gut out another Mets loss in another disappointing season, hoping for one more win out of a club that would go 5-7 down the stretch and end the season at 75-86. 
I have no doubt that on Friday night, when the Mets open the National League Division Series at Dodger Stadium staring down the most intimidating Los Angeles starting duo since Drysdale and Koufax, that the father and son I sat behind in Montreal will be watching. 
After sitting through eight years of low-budget rosters, trade deadline sales, seasons that were over by July and Octobers filled with football, Mets Dad and Son — and all Mets fans — will deservedly have their passion rewarded.
